author: barnabemonnot
content: Just watched the talk, it is here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=leJHrvz-YY8&feature=youtu.be&t=3738

author: barnabemonnot
content: very interesting point about the spikiness. i wonder how related it is to this remark in tim's paper

author: barnabemonnot
content: it's also a pattern that reoccurs often in the simulations we do

author: barnabemonnot
content: one basefee increment exhausts the demand, it comes down, now txs can come in again

author: barnabemonnot
content: it doesn't oscillate forever if the demand is shifting but it is not disappearing as fast as one might expect

author: barnabemonnot
content: i was also wondering about juan's comments on UX, that some users were unhappy basefee was varying, sometimes drastically. one striking thing i noticed on one of the slides is how stable the miner tips are, they look remarkably independent of the basefee level, which is something we should expect. so i am guessing those who are unhappy with high basefee levels are those who pay for the transaction fees, i.e., users. but this seems more due to overall congestion than to basefee dynamics (the usual "will 1559 lower gas prices?")

author: barnabemonnot
content: there was also a nice proposal by onur solmaz on using a larger control window for adjusting basefee, if filecoin judges the frequency of update (once per block) is too high. maybe smoothes things a bit but you should expect it trades off stability of the basefee against instability of the tips https://ethresear.ch/t/a-mechanism-for-daily-autonomous-gas-price-stabilization/7762

author: barnabemonnot
content: anyways, i'd be really interested to look at the data so far, especially re: this pattern

author: sky.cactus
content:
Users should always be setting fee cap to their willingness to pay, or the limit of how much money they have available.  If UX is suffering, that suggests to me that users are either:
1. Trying to set fee cap like they used to set gas price, something we may have to train users away from.
2. Are barely willing to pay current base fee.
3. Are trying to sweep their account and maximize how much they get out.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is unfortunate that sweeping an account requires you to donate money to miners.

author: .vbuterin
content:
> How urgent do you think that is relative to shipping 1559 "v1"? My feeling is we're getting to the spot where the risk of tweaking the spec will be the main driver of delays, so we should probably keep things as close to what we have now (modulo small things like adding 2718 support, maybe having a better update rule given it doesn't change much of the spec, etc.), get it on mainnet, and we can update the mechanism in a future hard fork once we have real-world data.

As I mentioned a bit further down, I'm happy with a hard "no change" rule at this point

author: barnabemonnot
content: seems like it's 2. in that case
